paper_abstract: Unbiased black-box complexity was introduced as a refined complexity model for randomized search heuristics (Lehre and Witt (2012) [24]). For several problems, this notion avoids the unrealistically low complexity results given by the classical model of Droste et al. (2006) [10]. We show that for some problems the unbiased black-box complexity remains artificially small. More precisely, for two different formulations of an NP-hard subclass of the well-known PARTITION problem, we give mutation-only unbiased black-box algorithms having complexity O(n log n). This indicates that also the unary unbiased black-box complexity does not give a complete picture of the true difficulty of this problem for randomized search heuristics. (C) 2014 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
paper_title: The unbiased black-box complexity of partition is polynomial
